title-group.article-title: Design of noncircular bevel gear with concave pitch curve

contrib-group.aff: Department of Mechanical Design and Automation, Beihang University, China

abstract.p: Noncircular bevel gear can achieve variable transmission between intersecting axes. This article proposes the design method of high-order noncircular bevel gear with concave pitch curve. The parametric equations for driving and driven gear, addendum and dedendum surface under given transmission ratio and axis angle are established in a spherical polar coordinate system. The tooth profile equation of noncircular bevel gear is derived according to the generation method by using bevel gear cutter. The three-dimensional model for noncircular bevel gear is developed to verify the correctness of the design method.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Noncircular bevel gear is a kind of spatial gear mechanism which can be used to transmit the motion and power between two intersecting axes with variable transmission ratio. It has the advantages of compactness, smooth motion, and accurate transmission. Noncircular bevel gears are highly specialized, their application being found in some special instances such as limited slip differential, among others, where the variable transmission ratio between intersecting axes is required. However, the design and manufacturing of the noncircular bevel gears are more complicated than those of plane noncircular gears and bevel gears. Given that the pitch curve and tooth profile curves of the former are not plane curves, research progress on noncircular bevel gears was both slow at the local and international settings. The transmission theory remains unclear and presently lacks practical research, analysis, and calculation methods.1

Elliptical bevel gears as a kind of noncircular bevel gear are invention of MacCord2 and Grant,3 who analyzed a pair of spherical ellipses rolling on each other while fixed on their foci, their free foci moving at a constant distance from each other. The concept of N-lobed elliptical bevel gears was introduced without any formulation. Ollson4 presented a novel gear transmission mode in ‘Noncircular Bevel Gear’, which is the most systematic research in the noncircular bevel gear field. Ollson developed the design and manufacturing methods for noncircular bevel gear under spherical coordinates according to the design procedures for planar noncircular gear. Figliolini5 analyzed the pitch surface of N-lobed elliptical bevel gears. A number of domestic researchers have undertaken in-depth studies on the pitch curve, gear profile, and processing methods for noncircular gears. Wang et al.6 and Wang and Jiang7 applied the variable transmission ratio of noncircular gears in the limited-slip differential and published their patents. Jia et al.8–14 and Zhao et al.15,16 conducted relevant studies on the application of noncircular bevel gear in automobile differential gears with an equivalent design. Lin et al.17,18 studied the transmission performance of oval bevel gears and published a relevant patent.19 These research results can further improve gear theory and are useful in developing a more complete design and manufacturing systems. The results also have important scientific value in the extensive use of noncircular bevel gears.

Previous studies were based on equivalent design and provided approximate solutions for the design of noncircular bevel gears, but did not yield accurate solutions. The accurate mathematical models of noncircular bevel gear tooth profiles is proposed by Xia et al.20 and crown rack is introduced to envelop the tooth profile of noncircular bevel gear. But this method cannot envelop noncircular bevel gear with concave pitch curve. In this article, the parametric equations of the pitch, addendum, and dedendum curves for noncircular bevel gear were developed in a spherical polar coordinate system, and the tooth profile equation was derived based on the generation method by using bevel gear cutter. The 3D model for noncircular bevel gear is developed in Pro/E to verify the correctness of the design method.

sec.title: Extension of conical surface
sec.p:
As shown in Figure 2, a generalized conical surface ϕ=ϕ(θ) is generated by connecting the center of sphere O and the points on the spherical curve Γ. Γ serves as the intersection curve between ϕ=ϕ(θ) and sphere OR. A is the intersection point between Z-axis and the spherical surface OR. Points B and C are on Γ, respectively, positioned by θ and θ1. Two orthodromes, AC∧ and AB∧, are created over these three points. The segment of Γ from B to C is extended in the following way. Through point B and the sphere center O, a unique tangent plane BOC' can be confirmed. Plane BOC' and the spherical surface intersect at an orthodrome. A section BC'∧ was taken from this orthodrome and forms its arc length equal to that from point B to point C on Γ. sec.p:
An osculating circle cone is used to determine the concavity of the conical surface for noncircular bevel gear. As shown in Figure 3, the conical intersection arc around point C is tangent to the conical surface. ρ is the cone angle of the bevel gear cutter, ς is thus satisfied with (5)ς=3π2-δorς=δ+π2 Figure 3.

Using the cosine law for a spherical triangle, then (6)tanρ=-[sin2ϕ+ϕ'2(θ)]32cosϕ·sin2ϕ+2cosϕ·ϕ'2(θ)-sinϕ·ϕ″(θ)
When tanρ<0, the cone is convex, and when tanρ>0, the cone is concave.

sec.title: Pitch surface of noncircular bevel gear
sec.p: The pitch surface of noncircular bevel gear is a generalized cone. The intersection line of the addendum and dedendum surfaces with spherical surface is equidistant to the intersection line of the pitch surface with spherical surface. The tooth profiles of a noncircular bevel gear are distributed on the spherical surface, which is concentric with the vertex of the cone. Therefore, deduction about the pitch surface and the tooth surface of noncircular bevel gear can be transited to discussion about the intersection sphere curves between the pitch surfaces or the tooth surfaces and the sphere, that is, the pitch curve or tooth profile curve. For convenience, the discussions below are based on the spherical surface, which is concentric with the vertex of the cone with radius R=1.

Figure 4 presents two pitch surfaces in mesh. They can be expressed by ϕ1=ϕ1(θ1)and ϕ2=ϕ2(θ2), respectively. Pitch curves 1 and 2 are tangential to each other at point P. ϕ1 rotates about Z1-axis with the angular speed of ω1, while ϕ2 rotates about Z2-axis at ω2. The velocities of pitch curves 1 and 2 at point P are νP1 and νP2. The included angle between Z1-axis and Z2-axis is ϕ0. In Figure 5, it is assumed that ϕ1 rotates around Z1-axis through angle θ1 and ϕ2 rotates about Z2-axis through an angle θ2. So the transmission ratio of this noncircular bevel gear pair can be described as (7)i12=ω1ω2=dθ1/dtdθ2/dt=1F'(θ1)=f(θ1) Figure 4.
Spherical engagements of pitch curves.
1 – Pitch surface; 2 – Circular conical surface.
Figure 5.
Elliptic bevel gear.

When a pair of noncircular bevel gears is in conjugate action, their pitch surfaces should achieve pure rolling. So at the instantaneous meshing point P, the relative velocity of the two pitch curves should be zero, namely, |νP1|=|νP2|. Since |νP1|=R·sinϕ1·ω1 and |νP2|=R·sinϕ2·ω2, it results in (8)i12=f(θ1)=sinϕ2sinϕ1=sin(ϕ0-ϕ1)sinϕ1
The pitch curve equation of the driving gear 1 can be expressed as (9)ϕ1=arctansinϕ0cosϕ0+f(θ1)
Moreover, the pitch curve equation of the driven gear 2 can be depicted as (10){θ2=∫0θ11f(θ1)dθ1ϕ2=ϕ0-ϕ1=ϕ0-arctansinϕ0cosϕ0+f(θ1)
Based on the previous expressions, the pitch curve equations of noncircular bevel gear can be concluded when the included angle between the two rotary axes and the transmission ratio are given.

sec.title: Closed conditions of the pitch curve
sec.p: Both pitch curves of the meshing gears should be closed if it is required that the gears perform unidirectional and continuous transmission to ensure a periodic kinematic relationship. However, the curves are closed only in some special conditions.

For the driving gear, the condition is as follow: i12 is the periodic function of θ1 and the number of periods is integral (expressed by n1) when θ1 varies from 0 to 2π. As a result, the polar angle ϕ1 goes through the same number of periods, and it remains the same value at θ1=0 and θ1=2π.

For the driven gear, the condition is similar: i12 is the periodic function of θ2 and the number of periods is integer (expressed by n2) when θ2varies from 0 to 2π. As a result, the polar angle ϕ2 complete the same number of periods, and it remains the same value at θ2=0 and θ2=2π.

When i12 varies for a whole period, the perigon of driving gear 1 is 2πn1 while the perigon of driven gear 2 is 2πn2 at the same time. Along with Equations (9) and (10), the closed conditions of the pitch curve for driven gear can be represented by an expression (11)2πn2=∫02πn1sinϕ1sinϕ0·cosϕ1-cosϕ0·sinϕ1dθ1

sec.p: Elliptical bevel gear is a kind of noncircular bevel gear with closed pitch curve. sec.title: Addendum and dedendum surfaces of noncircular bevel gear
sec.p:
As shown in Figure 6, the Z-axis and spherical surface OR intersect at point A. The numbers 1, 2, and 3 represent the dedendum, pitch, and dedendum curves, respectively. BC∧ is the normal arc of the pitch curve at point P. Orthodromes AC∧, AP∧, and AB∧ are created over point A, with β, ϕ, and γ as their central angles over points C, P, and B, respectively. ζ denotes the included angle of tangent lines of orthodromes AP∧ and BP∧ at point P, also known as the included angle of AP∧ and BP∧; ξ is the included angle of AP∧ and CP∧; δ denotes the tangent azimuth angle of the pitch curve at point P. When δ<π2, then ζ=δ+π2 and ξ=π2-δ; when δ>π2, then ζ=3π2-δ and ξ=δ-π2; αa is the addendum angle, and αa=ha*·αm; αf is the dedendum angle, and αf=(ha*+c*)·αm; ha* is the addendum factor, and ha*=1; c* is the clearance factor, and c*=0.25; and αm is the modular angle, which is defined as the degree of the central angle sector extended from the conic part divided by π. Such a conic part is derived from the pitch surface, which is at the same side of the tooth surface for the adjacent teeth. Δθγ is the included angle of AP∧ and AB∧, known as relative perigon of the pitch curve and the addendum curve at an equidistant point. Δθβ is the included angle of AP∧ and AC∧, known as relative perigon of the pitch curve and the dedendum curve at an equidistant point. Figure 6.
Features of addendum curve and dedendum curve.
1 – Dedendum curve; 2 – Pitch curve; 3 – Addendum curve.

sec.title: Tooth profile of noncircular bevel gear
sec.p: According to meshing theory and creating method of conjugate profiles, a couple of gears can be generated by a pair of cutters, which contented with the following conditions: The two cutter tooth profiles are conjugate and the relative movement between the cutter pitch surface and the gear pitch surface is true rolling while generating.

Theoretically, it would be feasible that a conjugate bevel gear pair is adopted to generate another bevel gear pair. So a bevel gear cutter conjugating with itself is introduced to produce the noncircular bevel gears. If the bevel gear cutter pitch surface rolls around the pitch surfaces of the gears from a certain position, a pair of conjugate gear tooth profiles can be obtained.

For two gears, if the modules and engaging angle are the same, inter-mesh transmission can be achieved regardless of the number of teeth, such that one bevel gear cutter can be used to process gears with various teeth.

In order to ensure the complete tooth shape, the number of teeth should meet the following condition (19)S1S2=z1z2 where S1 denotes the pitch curve length of the cutter and S1=2π·sinϕN, ϕN denotes the cone angle of the bevel gear cutter, S2 denotes the pitch curve length of the noncircular bevel gear and S2=∫02πsin2ϕ+ϕ'2(θ)dθ, z1 and z2 are the teeth numbers of the cutter and the noncircular bevel gear, respectively.

As shown in Figure 7, D is the intersection point of the tooth profile and the pitch curve of the cutter. Under the initial state, the pitch curves of the cutter and the noncircular bevel gear are tangent at point D(N). According to the basic law of tooth profile engagement, the common normal arc AC∧ will certainly cross point D. Figure 7.
Initial position of the cutter.
1 – Pitch curve of cutter; 2 – Pitch curve of gear; 3 – Tooth profile of cutter; 4 – Tooth profile of gear; 5 – Common normal arc.
Based on the properties of the involute tooth profile (20)AB∧=AD∧=sin(ϕB)·ɛ where ɛ is the included angle of O1A∧ and O1B∧.
Based on the cosine law for a spherical triangle (21)ɛ=arccos[cos(ϕD)cos(ϕB)]sin(ϕB)
Then (22)θN=ɛ-arctan{tan[sin(ϕB)·ɛ]sin(ϕB)}

The tooth profile of a gear is formed when the cutter and gear blank are purely rolling along the pitch curve and are enveloped by the tooth profile of the cutter. Different pitch curves envelope different tooth profiles. Therefore, the tooth profile of each gear tooth for noncircular bevel gear differs and so do the two sides of the same gear tooth.

The meshing segment of one tooth profile can be described by four subsections: right upper, right lower, left lower, and left upper tooth profile, as shown in Figure 8. The right tooth profile in the upside of the pitch surface from point A to the positive Z-axis is defined as the right upper tooth profile. Others are defined similarly. Figure 8.
Analytic graph for tooth profile.
1 – Pitch curve of cutter; 2 – Pitch curve of gear; 3 – Tooth profile of cutter; 4 – Tooth profile of gear; 5 – Common normal arc.

The right upper tooth profile of a noncircular bevel gear is generated when the pitch curve of the cutter purely rolls along the pitch curve of this noncircular bevel gear at a counterclockwise direction, as shown in Figure 8(a). At that moment, the rotation angle of the cutter is θ3, and the rotation angle of the noncircular bevel gear is θ4. The engaged point D on the pitch curves of the cutter and the noncircular bevel gear under initial condition move to D1 and D2, respectively. The tooth profiles are engaged at point N. A1C1∧ denotes the common normal arc. Orthodromes O2D∧ and O2N∧ are placed over O2 and engaged at points D and N.
The pitch curves of a purely rolling gear. According to the distance formula for a spherical curve (23)DD1∧=DD2∧=sin(ϕD)·θ3=∫0θ4sin2ϕ+ϕ'2(θ)dθ

Suppose α1 is the corresponding central angle of DN∧, and σ1 is the included angle of A1D∧ and O1D∧. For the spherical triangle ΔDO1N, based on the cosine law for a spherical triangle (25)α1=arccos[cos(ϕN1)·cos(ϕD)+sin(ϕN1)·sin(ϕD) ·cos(θ3+θN1-θN)] (26)σ1=arccos[cos(ϕN1)-cosα1·cos(ϕD)sinα1·sin(ϕD)]

For the spherical triangle ΔDO2N, based on the cosine law for a spherical triangle (27){ϕru=arccos[cosα1·cos(ϕ)-sinα1·sin(ϕ)·cosσ1]θru=θ4-arccos[cosα1-cos(ϕru)·cos(ϕ)sin(ϕru)·sin(ϕ)] where ϕru denotes the polar angle of the right upper tooth profile, θru denotes the perigon of the right upper tooth profile, and ϕ is the pitch curve equation of the noncircular bevel gear.
Thus, the right upper tooth profile is derived.

The right lower tooth profile of a noncircular bevel gear is generated when the pitch curve of a cutter is purely rolling along the pitch curve of this noncircular bevel gear in a clockwise direction, as shown in Figure 8(b). At that moment, the rotation angle of the cutter is θ5, and that of the noncircular bevel gear is θ6. The engaged point D on the pitch curves of the cutter and the noncircular bevel gear under initial condition move to D1 and D2, respectively. The tooth profiles engage at point N. A1C1∧ is the common normal arc. Orthodromes O2D∧ and O2N∧ are created over O2 and engage points D and N, respectively.

Assume α2 is the corresponding central angle of DN∧, and σ2 is the included angle of A1D∧ and O1D∧. For the spherical triangle ΔDO1N, based on the cosine law for a spherical triangle (29)α2=arccos[cos(ϕN2)·cos(ϕD) +sin(ϕN2)·sin(ϕD)·cos(θ5+θN-θN2)] (30)σ2=arccos[cosα2·cos(ϕD)-cos(ϕN2)sinα2·sin(ϕD)]

For the spherical triangle ΔDO2N, based on the cosine law for a spherical triangle, (31){ϕrl=arccos[cosα2·cos(ϕ)+sinα2·sin(ϕ)·cos(σ2)]θrl=θ6+arccos[cosα2-cos(ϕrl)·cos(ϕ)sin(ϕrl)·sin(ϕ)] where ϕrl denotes the polar angle of the right lower tooth profile, θrl denotes the perigon of the right lower tooth profile, and ϕ is the pitch curve equation of the noncircular bevel gear.
Thus, the right lower tooth profile is derived.

The left lower tooth profile of a noncircular bevel gear is generated when the cutter rolls p2 length (p denotes the tooth space of the bevel gear cutter) along the pitch curve of this noncircular bevel gear in a counterclockwise direction and then rotates θ7 as shown in Figure 8(c). At that moment, the rotation angle of the noncircular bevel gear is θ8. The engaged point D on the pitch curves of the cutter and the noncircular bevel gear under initial condition move to D1 and D2, respectively. The tooth profile engages at point N. A1C1∧ is the common normal arc. Orthodromes O2D∧ and O2N∧ are created over O2 and engage points D and N, respectively.

Assume α3 is the corresponding central angle of DN∧, and σ3 is the included angle of A1D∧ and O1D∧. For the spherical triangle ΔDO1N, based on the cosine law for a spherical triangle (33)α3=arccos[cos(ϕN3)·cos(ϕD)+sin(ϕN3) ·sin(ϕD)·cos(θ7+θN-θN3)] (34)σ3=arccos[cosα3·cos(ϕD)-cos(ϕN3)sinα3·sin(ϕD)]

For the spherical triangle ΔDO2N, based on the cosine law for a spherical triangle, (35){ϕll=arccos[cosα3·cos(ϕ)+sinα3·sin(ϕ)·cos(σ3)]θll=θ8-arccos[cosα3-cos(ϕll)·cos(ϕ)sin(ϕll)·sin(ϕ)] where ϕll denotes the polar angle of the left lower tooth profile, θll denotes the perigon of the left lower tooth profile, and ϕ is the pitch curve equation of the noncircular bevel gear.
Thus, the left lower tooth profile is derived.

The left upper tooth profile of a noncircular bevel gear is generated when the cutter rolls p2-θ9 length (p denotes the tooth space of the bevel gear cutter) along the pitch curve of this noncircular bevel gear in a counterclockwise direction as shown in Figure 8(d). At that moment, the rotation angle of the noncircular bevel gear is θ10. The engaged point D on the pitch curves of the cutter and the noncircular bevel gear under initial condition move to D1 and D2, respectively. The tooth profiles engage at point N. A1C1∧ is the common normal arc. Orthodromes O2D∧ and O2N∧ are created over O2 and engage points D and N, respectively.

Assume α4 is the corresponding central angle of DN∧, and σ4 is the included angle of ND∧ and O1D∧. For the spherical triangle ΔDO1N, based on the cosine law for a spherical triangle (37)α4=arccos[cos(ϕN4)·cos(ϕD)+sin(ϕN4) ·sin(ϕD)·cos(θ9+θN4-θN)] (38)σ4=arccos[cos(ϕN4)-cosα4·cos(ϕD)sinα4·sin(ϕD)]
For the spherical triangle ΔDO2N, based on the cosine law for a spherical triangle, (39){ϕlu=arccos[cosα4·cos(ϕ)-sinα4·sin(ϕ)·cos(σ4)]θlu=θ10+arccos[cosα4-cos(ϕlu)·cos(ϕ)sin(ϕlu)·sin(ϕ)]
Where ϕlu denotes the polar angle of the left upper tooth profile, θlu denotes the perigon of the left upper tooth profile, and ϕ is the pitch curve equation of the noncircular bevel gear.
Thus, the left upper tooth profile is derived.

sec.title: Example
sec.p: Suppose φ=17∘,λ=30∘, according to equation (13), the transmission ratio is (40)i12=1-2·sin(17∘)·cosθ12·cos(17∘)-3
When n2=1, assign bevel gear cutter number z1=18, noncircular bevel gear number z2=40, modular angle αm=S1·180∘z1·π·π, addendum angle αa=ha*·αm, and dedendum angle αf=(ha*+c*)·αm.
For the selection of the base circle, the addendum bevel angle should be ensured to be larger than the basic circular bevel angle, that is, αB>αa=αm. In this calculation, suppose αB=1.05αm.
Using equation (6) for the first-order and second-order bevel gear, tanρ<0, so the cone is convex, and for the third-order bevel gear, tanρ>0, so the cone is concave.

sec.title: Summary
sec.p:
The noncircular bevel gear can be used for variable transmission ratio driving. This article proposed the design of noncircular bevel gear with concave pitch curve and undertook the following tasks:
A spherical polar coordinate was developed based on the principles for spherical engagement, and the equations of the gear tooth surface for a noncircular bevel gear was developed by analyzing the relationship among the pitch curve, tooth profile curve, and line of engagement.
A method for processing noncircular bevel gear using bevel gear cutter enveloping was proposed, and the equations of the tooth profile for noncircular bevel gear were derived based on the principle of a spherical triangle.
The process of enveloping noncircular bevel gear by bevel gear cutter was simulated, and the 3D models of noncircular bevel gear were derived. The calculated result by equations is compared with the simulated generation result to verify its correctness.
